Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Secure packages and confirm successful delivery
Situation2: Leaving a package safely at the doorstep when no one is home
Story: I stared at my phone, the family group chat lighting up with reminders about tonight’s dinner. Mom’s message was clear: “Don’t be late, everyone. It’s important we’re all together.” I could almost hear her voice, warm but firm, and I knew how much these gatherings meant to her. As the oldest sister, I was expected to set an example, to show up and help keep the family close. But my delivery app pinged at the same time, assigning me a last-minute package drop across town. The customer’s note was strict: “Please make sure the package is hidden and safe. Call me after delivery.” I felt the pressure mounting—my boss expected reliability, and customers counted on me to keep their things secure. I glanced at the clock, calculating if I could do both, but the delivery window overlapped with dinner. My heart pounded as I weighed the disappointment in my mother’s eyes against the risk of a bad review and letting down my team. Torn between being the dependable sister and the responsible delivery person, I sat in my car, keys in hand, unable to move.
